conversation.message: Hello School_E—I'm Student_C. I’m exploring fit and wanted to learn more about your academic strengths and student support (especially for students aiming for strong exam results). What qualities do you prioritize most in applicants, and what programs/resources are you most proud of?
conversation.thought: School_E is my last choice. I should avoid committing early and keep options open for School_D/A/B/C where I may have a better outcome. Use this round to gather information and signal mild interest without applying.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_C—thanks for reaching out. At School_E, our biggest academic strength is structured, exam-focused instruction paired with consistent individual support.

What we prioritize in applicants: intellectual curiosity, steady work habits, and resilience—students who set goals, respond well to feedback, and keep improving over time.

Programs/resources we’re most proud of:
- Exam strategy support: regular diagnostic assessments, targeted review plans, and practice under timed conditions.
- Small-group tutoring/office hours: subject teachers run weekly help sessions, and we add short-term intensives before major exams.
- Advising & study planning: each student has an advisor who helps track progress, adjust study routines, and choose the right course level.
- Student support: clear check-ins for workload/stress management and quick intervention if performance dips.

If you share which subjects you’re aiming to strengthen (and your target exam level), I can describe the specific supports and typical pathways here. We’d be excited to learn more about your goals and see if School_E is a strong fit for you.
conversation.thought: Student_C is #2 on our true priority list, so we should actively appeal and keep them engaged toward applying soon. No prior interactions; early round. Provide strong academic/support details and signal enthusiasm without committing to accept unless they apply.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions, I’m Student_D. School_A is one of my top choices because I value the academic rigor and the environment for motivated students. If admitted, I’m ready to commit and would be excited to contribute to the school community. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_A is my 2nd choice (high). I also have very strong priority at School_B (ranked #1 there) and School_D, but I’m not talking to them this round. At School_A, I’m ranked #2 (behind Student_B), and Student_B’s top choice is School_B, so School_A is plausibly attainable. To secure a good outcome early, I should apply now rather than just talk.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_D,

Thank you for your application and for sharing why School_A is a great fit for you. We value students who are motivated by academic rigor and who will contribute positively to our community.

We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. We would be excited to welcome you and support your goals here.

Sincerely,
School_A Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_D is #2 on School_A’s true priority list (only behind Student_B). With quota 1 and no existing matches, accepting Student_D now secures a very high-priority outcome. While Student_B is ranked higher, Student_B’s top choice is School_B and School_A is only their 3rd choice, so waiting is risky. Student_D has applied and expressed strong interest in School_A, making acceptance the best move to maximize priority within capacity.

conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team—I'm Student_A. School_D is one of my top options because I value a structured academic environment and strong student support. Could you share what qualities you prioritize most this year (e.g., grades, interviews, specific activities)? I’d like to understand how to best present my fit.
conversation.thought: School_D is my 3rd choice. My top choice School_A likely prefers Student_B and Student_D over me, so my chance there is moderate-to-low. School_C ranks me last, so it’s very unlikely I get in. School_D ranks me last as well, so applying now risks an immediate reject unless higher-priority students don’t apply. Since it’s early (round 1), I should gather information and express interest without committing, keeping flexibility to pursue School_A first.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_A—thanks for reaching out. At School_D, we look for students who will thrive in a structured environment and contribute positively to the community. In general, we prioritize: (1) consistent academic performance and evidence of strong study habits, (2) interview readiness—clear goals, maturity, and willingness to engage with feedback, and (3) sustained commitments (clubs, service, leadership, or long-term activities) that show responsibility rather than just a long list of short stops.

If you’d like, share 2–3 examples of how you’ve handled a challenging workload or supported others in a group setting—those kinds of specifics tend to come through strongly in interviews and applications.
conversation.thought: Student_A is last on School_D’s true priority list. With quota 1, we should avoid signaling strong commitment and instead gather info while keeping options open for higher-priority students (Student_D/E/C/B). Since Student_A initiated TALK, respond with TALK and provide general criteria without implying likely acceptance.

conversation.message: Hello School_C. You are my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining your community. I’m ready to commit if offered a spot and would be honored to be considered this round. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: School_C is my top choice. I’m 4th in School_C’s priority list (after C, B, D), so acceptance isn’t guaranteed, but applying immediately is the best way to secure a chance before the seat fills. No prior commitments exist yet, so I should apply now and express strong commitment.

conversation.message: Thank you, Student_E. We’re honored to be your first choice, and we appreciate your clear commitment. We would be excited to welcome you to School_C—your application is accepted, and we’re happy to offer you our spot this round. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is on our true priority list (4th of 5). With quota 1, accepting now secures a solid match, but we may be able to attract higher-priority Students C/B/D in later rounds. Since Student_E ranks us first-choice and is ready to commit, accepting yields a guaranteed match and avoids the risk of ending unmatched if top candidates commit elsewhere. Given no prior interactions and round 1 uncertainty, accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_B—I'm Student_B. School_B is my first-choice school and my top priority in this market. I’m very eager to join your program and would commit if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_B is my top choice. I have decent priority at School_B (3rd), but Student_D and Student_A rank ahead of me and may also apply, so I should apply immediately to maximize my chance rather than risk losing the only seat.

conversation.message: Student_B, thank you for your application and for ranking School_B as your first choice. We’re excited about your strong fit and commitment—School_B would be happy to have you join our program. Welcome to School_B!
conversation.thought: Student_B is on our true priority list (3rd). They rank us #1, so accepting likely secures a stable match immediately. While Student_D and Student_A are higher on our list, they do not rank us first and may be captured by their top choices (Student_D prefers School_C/A/B; Student_A prefers School_A/C/D/B). With quota 1 and no guarantee we can land D or A later, accepting a top-interested, mid-high priority candidate is a strong outcome and avoids ending unmatched.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions team—I'm Student_A. I’m exploring my remaining options carefully and wanted to learn more about School_E’s selection priorities this year. What factors matter most in your evaluation (academics, interview, activities, fit), and what would make an applicant stand out to you? Also, are you expecting to finalize matches quickly in the next round or two? I’m very interested in finding a strong mutual fit.
conversation.thought: School_E is last on my true preference list, but only School_D and School_E remain unmatched in round 2, so I should keep School_E as a safety while trying to learn whether an application would be competitive. School_E’s priority ranks me #1, which makes it a strong fallback if I can’t secure School_D. I will TALK (not APPLY yet) to preserve flexibility and gather info about their process and timeline, while signaling genuine interest.

conversation.message:
Hi Student_A—thanks for reaching out. We can be very transparent about what we value at School_E.

Selection priorities (in practice):
- Academics & trajectory: strong fundamentals plus evidence of steady improvement (recent performance and consistency matter a lot).
- Work habits: reliability, follow-through, and how you respond to feedback—students who iterate and get better quickly tend to thrive here.
- Fit with an exam-focused environment: comfort with structured practice, diagnostics, and targeted review plans.
- Interview/interaction: clarity of goals, coachability, and maturity in managing workload.
- Activities: valued when they show sustained commitment/leadership, but they’re secondary to academic readiness and fit.

What makes an applicant stand out:
- A clear target (what level/schools you’re aiming for) and a concrete plan for how you study.
- Evidence you’ve overcome a weak area (e.g., math accuracy, reading speed) through deliberate practice.
- Specific interest in our supports (diagnostics → individualized study plan → small-group tutoring/office hours), not just a generic “good school” preference.

On timing: yes—we’re prepared to finalize matches quickly in the next round or two if there’s strong mutual intent.

If School_E is one of your top remaining options, I’d encourage you to apply as soon as you’re ready. Also, if you tell me (1) your strongest/weakest subjects and (2) your exam goals, I can outline the most typical pathway and supports you’d use here.
conversation.thought: Student_A is #1 on School_E’s true priority list and currently unmatched; we have quota 1. Student_C (also high priority) is still unmatched, but securing Student_A is optimal. Student_A is only exploring and asked about priorities and timing; we should actively appeal and encourage an APPLY next round while signaling we can move quickly and that they are a strong fit if they value structured exam support. Since they sent [TALK], respond with [TALK] and prompt for an application.

conversation.message: Hello School_D—I'm Student_C. School_D is my first choice, and I’m excited by the focus on strong academics and a motivated student community. I’m ready to commit to School_D if offered a place, and I’d love the opportunity to contribute and thrive in your program. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_D is my top choice. It is still unmatched in round 2 and I have relatively strong priority there (3rd after Student_D and Student_E). Since only School_D and School_E remain unmatched, delaying risks losing School_D if Student_E applies and is accepted. Best move is to apply now and emphasize fit and commitment.

conversation.message: Student_C—thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We appreciate your clear commitment and the fit you describe with our academic culture and motivated community. We’re pleased to offer you a place at School_D. Welcome—we look forward to having you contribute and thrive here.
conversation.thought: Student_C is on School_D’s true priority list (3rd). With quota 1 and only Student_A and Student_C unmatched, accepting Student_C now secures a high-priority match. Student_D and Student_E (higher priorities) are already matched elsewhere, so waiting offers little upside and risks ending unmatched or matching with a lower-priority student. Student_C also ranks School_D as first choice, making the match stable.

conversation.message: Hello School_E admissions team—thank you for the information earlier. After considering my options, I’d like to formally apply to School_E. I’m confident I’d contribute positively to the community through consistent academic effort and active participation, and I’m excited about the possibility of joining. [APPLY]
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched in round 3, so securing a match now is important to avoid going unmatched. School_E is on my preference list (though last), and School_E ranks me #1 in its priority list, making acceptance very likely if I apply. Since I have not applied to School_E yet and there are no higher-ranked schools left available, I should apply now to lock in a match.

conversation.message: Student_A—thank you for your application. We’re excited about the possibility of you joining School_E, and your emphasis on consistent academic effort and active participation aligns strongly with what we value here. We would be happy to move forward and finalize your placement with us. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_A is #1 on School_E’s true priority list. We have remaining quota 1 and no current match, and Student_A is the only unmatched student left, so accepting secures our top-choice outcome immediately.
